webTitle: Recovery revisited: the surprise political punch of the beloved 90s music show

fields.headline: Recovery revisited: the surprise political punch of the beloved 90s music show
fields.standfirst: A new ABC documentary relives the wackiness on every Saturday from 1996 to 2000 in a show more radical than you may remember
fields.trailText: A new ABC documentary relives the wackiness on every Saturday from 1996 to 2000 in a show more radical than you may remember
fields.body:
In a full embrace of 90s nostalgia, I donned a pair of brown corduroy trousers, cracked a cold longneck of Carlton Draught and settled in to watch Recovery: The Music & The Mayhem, a documentary about the generation-defining ABC music show that aired on Saturday mornings from 1996 to 2000.

Celebrated for bringing local and international bands into suburban living rooms, it was also rife with pranks, games and zany segments that took in everything from nude lawn-mowing to horror movies.

But while it was a thrill to relive the tide of wackiness Recovery embodied, perhaps the documentary is most interesting in its attempt to create a coherent narrative about a show that often lacked one.

Featuring interviews with hosts Dylan Lewis, Jane Gazzo, the show’s producers and a slew of musicians, it makes the case that not only did Recovery provide a stage for Regurgitator to sing I Piss Alone in skintight spacesuits, it also helped shape politics and Indigenous affairs.

Related: Is there a better televisual sleep aid than the soporific joy of Escape to the Country?

Perhaps this is why the show attracted concern from those in power. With what we now know about what was happening in the 90s – the emerging revelations of the child abuse that was rife within the Catholic church, for a start – it’s shocking to think that the Howard government wasted federal parliament’s time debating the corrupting influence of Lewis’s eyebrow ring. It was the ABC corrupting Australia’s youth?

During an interview with US hip-hop group Public Enemy after their performance of He Got Game/Shake Your Booty in 1998, the group expressed their solidarity with Indigenous Australians. Flava Flav said, “We made a pact with the Aborigines. They gave me a flag,” then signalled to the house band Nokturnl, who had brought their protest songs to the studio from Alice Springs.

Chuck D held up a Welcome to Country sign for the Wurundjeri people, a precursor to the widescale adoption of the ceremony we have today, before calling out Pauline Hanson. Even two years after the One Nation senator’s maiden speech to parliament, her inflammatory rhetoric about the country being “swamped by Asians” was still creating divisions. “I wrote a poem about the perils of Pauline,” Chuck D told Lewis, “and we’re going to drop it tonight in Brisbane.”

Another one of the show’s explicitly political moments was Powderfinger’s performance of The Day You Come – a song which, the documentary makes clear, also spoke to Hanson’s racism. To my ear, their music was like being smothered in beige – but on reflection, maybe that’s a little rough.

Listening back to their Recovery performance, the song does capture something of the bewilderment that abounded at the time: how could Hanson’s open hatred have been the people’s choice? There is a subtlety to the way Bernard Fanning turns the knife in the chorus, as if trying to lower Hanson’s tone to a whisper so that we all might hear her venom. The documentary suggests that the toxic political legacy of the 90s is still evident today, where Hanson has reemerged as part of a global populist movement.

Although Frenzal Rhomb never targeted politicians directly, their seeming ubiquity on the show felt like a dirty middle finger to the pantomime taking place in Canberra, and to adulthood at large. The sheer chaos and unpredictability of their appearances was enough to get the grey hairs in my house shaking their heads. “He doesn’t look like he’s had a shower in months,” my mother would say, glancing over my shoulder at Jay Whalley. “And why does he have purple dreadlocks? I wouldn’t even know where to buy that colour.”

Related: Reheated cooking and 'horny reality': the major networks have jumped the shark

As a teenager at home, watching the blast of Punch In The Face felt more than cathartic; it felt something like freedom. I didn’t fully comprehend the song’s class commentary and lambasting of “middle class white boys,” but I could sense that these punks who seemed like they could barely play their instruments had married stupidity and anti-authority in a way that was uniquely Australian. They were larrikins.

Oh nostalgia, there’s life in you yet. I’m off to put batteries in my walkman and trawl eBay for original Tumbleweed concert posters – and one of the Enforcer’s T-shirts.

• Recovery: The Music & the Mayhem is streaming on iView

webTitle: Clare Bowditch, Tim Flannery and Blanche  d'Alpuget  on what they're reading this month

fields.headline: Clare Bowditch, Tim Flannery and Blanche  d'Alpuget  on what they're reading this month
fields.standfirst: Plus Jeff Sparrow on fascism after Christchurch, Ceridwen Dovey on knowledge and Carmel Bird on Lewis Carroll
fields.trailText: Plus Jeff Sparrow on fascism after Christchurch, Ceridwen Dovey on knowledge and Carmel Bird on Lewis Carroll
fields.byline: Blanche d'Alpuget, Carmel Bird, Clare Bowditch, Jeff Sparrow, Ceridwen Dovey, Tim Flannery, Robyn Annear
fields.body:
Blanche d’Alpuget
The Complete Biography of Bob Hawke
Simon & Schuster

Tell us about your book. The Complete Biography of Bob Hawke is a work that has taken me 40 years to research and write. This final version features significant revision of his time in office, reflecting new information and perspective on his relationship with Paul Keating and a brand new third part from the time he left public office through to his death.

From before his birth, it traces the life of a man who was the most famous Australian political figure of the second half of the 20th century. He may be deemed one of the nation’s greatest sons, rising from offspring of a minister in a small congregational church to become a Rhodes scholar who turned his back on academia and business to fight for working people’s wages, to lead the trade union movement, then to become Labor’s longest-serving prime minister. By the age of 29 Hawke was the working class’s rockstar (and bogeyman for conservatives); by 40 he was the second-most powerful man in the country, and at 54 the most powerful. He inspired the nation to follow him in modernising the economy and society; he fought like a tiger against apartheid in South Africa, he uplifted the status of women, he protected the wellbeing of children, he launched a campaign of environmental care when the idea was hardly of interest. He was honoured by governments around the world and on his death in May 2019 was deeply mourned by the nation.

Women threw themselves at him; he rarely threw them back, but throughout his life he battled a demonic weakness for alcohol. The archetype of the Aussie larrikin, he was blessed with a brilliant intellect, love of people of all ages, colours and faiths, and a passion for life itself. His virtues were manifold; so were his flaws.

What were you reading while you wrote it? While writing this book I read too many others to list, although two of my favourites from those days are The Death of Napoleon by Simon Leys and Leaves of Grass and Selected Poems and Prose by Walt Whitman.

What will you read next? Having read Bruce Pascoe’s Dark Emu, the next books on my list are Sand Talk by Tyson Yunkaporta and How to Defend Australia by Hugh White.

Carmel Bird
Field of Poppies
Transit Lounge

Tell us about your book. Field of Poppies is my response to the sense of impending catastrophe currently gripping the global imagination. It places the first world war in the frame as a starting point from which to view the progress of apocalypse. Present day tree-changers are seeking a better life in the goldfields’ country of Victoria. They discover that, while life seems pleasant enough, even dreamlike, the past was ugly and the future promises to be grotesque.

Their house is robbed, their neighbour is abducted. Then the whole area is disrupted and horribly transformed by the arrival of a new Chinese goldmine. People are sleepwalking through this latest phase of the end-of-the-world, where the seas are rising, the animals and plants are disappearing, leaders are apparently insane, resources are running out. The scarlet poppy acts as a signature that binds the sleepers to the terrible events of the past and offers them nightmares in the future.

What were you reading while you wrote it? Lewis Carroll’s Alice books for the umpteenth time. The characters in my novel read these at book group for the first time. So in a strange way I was a character who was reading them afresh. (Although everybody knows a lot about them, not everybody has actually read them.)

What will you read next? Bruny by Heather Rose. The author is a marvellous writer. I believe the issues raised in Bruny coincide with those pursued in Field of Poppies. So I am keen to immerse myself in another novelist’s imaginative approach to the “new world order” as it is articulated in southern Tasmania.

Clare Bowditch
Your Own Kind of Girl
Allen & Unwin

Tell us about your book. My book is not a traditional rock’n’roll memoir by any stretch: it is probably better described as a brutal, hopeful, coming-of-age memoir about the stories we humans tell ourselves and what happens when we believe them.

It’s about the question of personal power, and where the nexus of that power lies. It’s about how, believe it or not, we can live through and thrive in the shadow of real life – the long tail of childhood grief, the secret and sometimes absurd struggle we have with the size of our bodies. It’s also about the size of our dreams and our creative ambitions, and the challenges and triumphs of bringing them to life in a world that still somehow tells us (in ways subtle and obvious) that in order to “win”, we have to hide who we really are – our size, our opinions, our feelings.

At its heart, it is a love story for anyone who struggles with self-doubt, but also hidden in there is an instruction manual about how to live through and recover from an acute experience of mental ill-health. Mine hit at 21. Thanks to good help and good books, I lived to tell the tale, and then some. My life’s work is about passing on that hope.

What were you reading while you wrote it? I made a call to read very little as I wrote – deprivation of this pleasure was a great motivator in getting me to clock in my daily wordcount! But I did reread one old-fashioned underrated classic several times during my writing called Self Help for Your Nerves by Dr Claire Weekes. This was the book that saved my life at age 21. Bloody winner, that one.

What will you read next? I have three books Aussie books on my side table at the moment. The Woman Who Cracked the Anxiety Code – a biography of my hero Dr Claire Weekes by Judith Hoare (fine writer, fine topic). Paris or Die by Jayne Tuttle, one of my favourite Australian Parisian authors, who just moved back to the Victorian coast to run the Queenscliff bookstore. And Leigh Robshaw’s You Had Me at Hola: I did an event with Leigh in Maleny and she was a hoot. It’s self-published and apparently rather adventurous, I hear. Summer here I come!

Jeff Sparrow
Fascists Among Us: Online Hate and the Christchurch Massacre
Scribe

Tell us about your book. Fascists Among Us was written in the aftermath of the Christchurch massacre.

It’s an argument about the nature of 21st century fascism, an examination of the relationship between the extremely online fascism of Pepe memes and gun massacres and the old-style fascism of Nuremberg rallies and Blackshirts.

It looks at how the events of 9/11 reshaped the right as a whole, and how a distinctively fascist current exploited the new political environment. It traces the uses made by fascist activists of trolling, meming and internet culture as a whole; it unpicks new developments like “accelerationism” and “eco fascism”. Most of all, it argues that if we are to prevent further massacres, we need to understand the ideology driving them.

What were you reading while you wrote it? I read an advance copy of David Renton’s book The New Authoritarianism, which greatly influenced aspects of my argument.

What will you read next? After the Count by Stephanie Convery. Reader, I married her.

Ceridwen Dovey
Inner Worlds, Outer Spaces
Hamish Hamilton

Tell us about your book. This book is a collected edition of profiles I’ve written of people in unusual careers, from moon dust scientists to women’s rugby stars to space archaeologists to bibliotherapists. Most of the people I’ve profiled are Australian (among them Ian Thorpe and Liane Moriarty), and many have toiled long and hard in their respective fields over a lifetime, sustained by their deep passion for what they do. It has been my privilege to eavesdrop on their working lives, and to catch glimpses of bodies of knowledge and ways of being and working that are often inaccessible to outsiders. I hope that the book might inspire readers to reignite their own interests and obsessions, and perhaps even find a way to build a career around them.

What were you reading while you wrote it? I wrote these profiles over about seven years, and while writing them I read everything I could find by the people I was writing about, for insights into their daily work. Some standouts include Alice Gorman’s Dr Space Junk vs The Universe, Ella Berthoud and Susan Elderkin’s The Novel Cure: An A-Z of Literary Remedies, and Lyndall Ryan and Jane Lydon’s edited volume Remembering the Myall Creek Massacre.

What will you read next? The next Australian book I plan to read is Tyson Yunkaporta’s Sand Talk: How Indigenous Thinking Can Save the World. I’ve just started dipping into it and I’m already excited by the possibility of drawing on concepts from the book to think about outer space differently – since I’m currently obsessed with social and environmental justice in space, and how we can find new forms of relating out there instead of exporting our failed earthly traditions of narcissism and greed.

Tim Flannery
Life: Selected Writings
Text

Tell us about your book. Its a strange business looking back on 30 years of writing to select pieces for a collected work. I’m not terribly self-reflective, so my reading earlier works systematically was new for me. The trajectory the exercise revealed – an expansion of perspective with an odd circling back to various topics – was intriguing because I was unaware of it as I wrote. I came away from it feeling proud of some of my earlier works, especially my early attempts at understanding the Australian environment, and my adventures in New Guinea. They were rugged and edgy in a way my later writing was not.

It’s odd how things that might make you cringe at some stages of your life later look like virtues. Writing the introduction was the most difficult thing. After all, it has to be about the writer and his journey. I kept wishing that someone else could write it. But there it is, the most self-reflective piece I’ve ever penned.

What were you reading while you wrote it? James Scott’s Against the Grain. The earliest cities were gulags according to Scott, the city walls designed to keep people in rather than invaders out. A grim start to so-called civilisation – and what a journey us urbanites have been on over the past 6,000 years – a journey that continues with Extinction Rebellion and the protesters in Hong Kong.

What will you read next? Peter Temple’s The Red Hand. Its a posthumous collected works of an Australian writer of crime fiction who I greatly admire. I guess that producing my own collected works has made me curious to read more in the genre.

Robyn Annear
Nothing New
Text

Tell us about your book. It’s hard to imagine there was ever a time when new was an aberration and secondhand the norm. But it’s true: up until the mid-19th century it was usual for things to be passed and sold on until they were completely worn out. And even then, uses were found for them: cotton rags made paper, furniture for fuel, even food scraps and floor sweepings were recycled. There was, it was said, “no such thing as waste”.

Nothing New traces the history of second-hand, as a practice that gained a stigma only as consumerism taught us to venerate the new. Yet secondhand has kept breaking through, in guises ranging from jumble sales to the Trading Post, garage sales, the used-car trade, op shops and high-end vintage. Now, the flipside of fast fashion is peak secondhand. Nothing New celebrates secondhand as a pleasure, a deviance and a force for good.

What were you reading while you wrote it? Old newspapers, digitised and online at Trove, hosted by the National Library of Australia. Better than any other source, they brought me up close to people’s shifting relationship with secondhand over time. And breaking news carried the story forward – the recycling crisis, fashion pollution, the decluttering craze, op shops overwhelmed.

What will you read next? Andrew McGahan’s The Rich Man’s House promises to be a thrilling genre-buster and, at 600-odd pages, an immersive post-publication treat.

It’s also about the size of our dreams and our creative ambitions, and the challenges and triumphs of bringing them to life in a world that still somehow tells us (in ways subtle and obvious) that in order to “win”, we have to hide who we really are – our size, our opinions, our feelings. At its heart, it is a love story for anyone who struggles with self-doubt, but also hidden in there is an instruction manual about how to live through and recover from an acute experience of mental ill-health. Mine hit at 21. Thanks to good help and good books, I lived to tell the tale, and then some. My life’s work is about passing on that hope. What were you reading while you wrote it? I made a call to read very little as I wrote – deprivation of this pleasure was a great motivator in getting me to clock in my daily wordcount! But I did reread one old-fashioned underrated classic several times during my writing called Self Help for Your Nerves by Dr Claire Weekes. This was the book that saved my life at age 21. Bloody winner, that one. What will you read next? I have three books Aussie books on my side table at the moment. The Woman Who Cracked the Anxiety Code – a biography of my hero Dr Claire Weekes by Judith Hoare (fine writer, fine topic). Paris or Die by Jayne Tuttle, one of my favourite Australian Parisian authors, who just moved back to the Victorian coast to run the Queenscliff bookstore. And Leigh Robshaw’s You Had Me at Hola: I did an event with Leigh in Maleny and she was a hoot. It’s self-published and apparently rather adventurous, I hear. Summer here I come! Jeff Sparrow Fascists Among Us: Online Hate and the Christchurch Massacre Scribe Tell us about your book. Fascists Among Us was written in the aftermath of the Christchurch massacre. It’s an argument about the nature of 21st century fascism, an examination of the relationship between the extremely online fascism of Pepe memes and gun massacres and the old-style fascism of Nuremberg rallies and Blackshirts. It looks at how the events of 9/11 reshaped the right as a whole, and how a distinctively fascist current exploited the new political environment. It traces the uses made by fascist activists of trolling, meming and internet culture as a whole; it unpicks new developments like “accelerationism” and “eco fascism”. Most of all, it argues that if we are to prevent further massacres, we need to understand the ideology driving them. What were you reading while you wrote it? I read an advance copy of David Renton’s book The New Authoritarianism, which greatly influenced aspects of my argument. What will you read next? After the Count by Stephanie Convery. Reader, I married her. Ceridwen Dovey Inner Worlds, Outer Spaces Hamish Hamilton Tell us about your book. This book is a collected edition of profiles I’ve written of people in unusual careers, from moon dust scientists to women’s rugby stars to space archaeologists to bibliotherapists. Most of the people I’ve profiled are Australian (among them Ian Thorpe and Liane Moriarty), and many have toiled long and hard in their respective fields over a lifetime, sustained by their deep passion for what they do. It has been my privilege to eavesdrop on their working lives, and to catch glimpses of bodies of knowledge and ways of being and working that are often inaccessible to outsiders. I hope that the book might inspire readers to reignite their own interests and obsessions, and perhaps even find a way to build a career around them. What were you reading while you wrote it? I wrote these profiles over about seven years, and while writing them I read everything I could find by the people I was writing about, for insights into their daily work. Some standouts include Alice Gorman’s Dr Space Junk vs The Universe, Ella Berthoud and Susan Elderkin’s The Novel Cure: An A-Z of Literary Remedies, and Lyndall Ryan and Jane Lydon’s edited volume Remembering the Myall Creek Massacre. What will you read next? The next Australian book I plan to read is Tyson Yunkaporta’s Sand Talk: How Indigenous Thinking Can Save the World. I’ve just started dipping into it and I’m already excited by the possibility of drawing on concepts from the book to think about outer space differently – since I’m currently obsessed with social and environmental justice in space, and how we can find new forms of relating out there instead of exporting our failed earthly traditions of narcissism and greed. Tim Flannery Life: Selected Writings Text Tell us about your book. Its a strange business looking back on 30 years of writing to select pieces for a collected work. I’m not terribly self-reflective, so my reading earlier works systematically was new for me. The trajectory the exercise revealed – an expansion of perspective with an odd circling back to various topics – was intriguing because I was unaware of it as I wrote. I came away from it feeling proud of some of my earlier works, especially my early attempts at understanding the Australian environment, and my adventures in New Guinea. They were rugged and edgy in a way my later writing was not. It’s odd how things that might make you cringe at some stages of your life later look like virtues. Writing the introduction was the most difficult thing. After all, it has to be about the writer and his journey. I kept wishing that someone else could write it. But there it is, the most self-reflective piece I’ve ever penned. What were you reading while you wrote it? James Scott’s Against the Grain. The earliest cities were gulags according to Scott, the city walls designed to keep people in rather than invaders out. A grim start to so-called civilisation – and what a journey us urbanites have been on over the past 6,000 years – a journey that continues with Extinction Rebellion and the protesters in Hong Kong. What will you read next? Peter Temple’s The Red Hand. Its a posthumous collected works of an Australian writer of crime fiction who I greatly admire. I guess that producing my own collected works has made me curious to read more in the genre. Robyn Annear Nothing New Text Tell us about your book. It’s hard to imagine there was ever a time when new was an aberration and secondhand the norm. But it’s true: up until the mid-19th century it was usual for things to be passed and sold on until they were completely worn out. And even then, uses were found for them: cotton rags made paper, furniture for fuel, even food scraps and floor sweepings were recycled. There was, it was said, “no such thing as waste”. Nothing New traces the history of second-hand, as a practice that gained a stigma only as consumerism taught us to venerate the new. Yet secondhand has kept breaking through, in guises ranging from jumble sales to the Trading Post, garage sales, the used-car trade, op shops and high-end vintage. Now, the flipside of fast fashion is peak secondhand. Nothing New celebrates secondhand as a pleasure, a deviance and a force for good. What were you reading while you wrote it? Old newspapers, digitised and online at Trove, hosted by the National Library of Australia. Better than any other source, they brought me up close to people’s shifting relationship with secondhand over time. And breaking news carried the story forward – the recycling crisis, fashion pollution, the decluttering craze, op shops overwhelmed. What will you read next? Andrew McGahan’s The Rich Man’s House promises to be a thrilling genre-buster and, at 600-odd pages, an immersive post-publication treat.

webTitle: Liverpool will relish pressure of Salzburg decider, says Jürgen Klopp

fields.headline: Liverpool will relish pressure of Salzburg decider, says Jürgen Klopp
fields.standfirst:
• Reds need to avoid defeat in Austria to progress
• Fabinho could face spell on sidelines with ankle injury
fields.trailText: Jürgen Klopp said that Liverpool would relish a match away to RB Salzburg that will decide their Champions League fate after the 1-1 draw with Napoli at Anfield
fields.body:
Jürgen Klopp lamented Liverpool’s failure to book a Champions League “holiday” in Salzburg next month but insisted his European champions would thrive on the pressure to reach the knockout stages in Austria.

Related: Dries Mertens and Napoli show rivals that Liverpool have their flaws | Barney Ronay

Liverpool realistically need a draw from their final group game in Austria to reach the knockout stages having taken only a point from Napoli’s visit to Anfield on Wednesday. Victory against Carlo Ancelotti’s side would have secured qualification with a game to spare and eased the burden on Klopp’s first-team regulars during a demanding December of nine matches in four competitions. Fabinho, Liverpool’s influential midfielder, may be out of action for several games having sustained an ankle injury in the 1‑1 draw.

“I don’t want to say we need it [the pressure on the final game] but we had it always,” Klopp said. “I’m four years in – tell me when it was easy? Last year we had to win at home 1-0 against Napoli. I cannot remember a bigger pressure game than that. Really difficult and we did it. Now, we have to go to Salzburg. In this moment the game is over and my problem is Fabinho is injured and Brighton, not Salzburg.

“But I know how human beings are; people wished we could finish the group tonight and make kind of a holiday game in Salzburg. That’s the situation – if we have ambitions in the Champions League, we have to show that in Salzburg. Until then we have to show our ambitions in the Premier League.”

Klopp added: “It was clear that we wanted to finish it tonight. We knew long before the game that it would be difficult against Napoli. It was difficult last year, it’s always difficult. They’re a good side.”

Fabinho left Anfield with his left foot in a protective boot amid concerns he could be out for several weeks with ankle ligament damage. The Brazil midfielder will be assessed over the next 48 hours.

Klopp said of the injury: “I don’t know [the extent]. He has pain, so that’s not good. He couldn’t continue, and he is a really hard one. I don’t want to say what I expect, because I hope that it is not that serious but we will know more, maybe tomorrow, maybe the day after. We will see.”

webTitle: Dries Mertens and Napoli show rivals that Liverpool have their flaws | Barney Ronay

fields.headline: Dries Mertens and Napoli show rivals that Liverpool have their flaws
fields.standfirst: Premier League teams really could do a lot worse than study the tapes of these 180 Champions League minutes
fields.trailText: Premier League teams really could do a lot worse than study the tapes of these 180 Champions League minutes
fields.body:
For the opening hour at Anfield the Napoli players must have been tempted to wonder, once again, what exactly all the fuss is around here. Take to the field expecting the red swarm, the hammers of the Premier League, a process of extreme thrash‑metal disintegration. And what do you get?

Not quite that, it turns out. Napoli have done this four times now in two years. In the first half they had the Premier League leaders pinned, rhythms stilled by the swarm of light-blue shirts around their usual passing triangles. It took Liverpool 35 minutes to muster their first effort on target. Ten minutes later the players walked off at the interval looking a little baffled, the crowd silenced, air sucked out of this tight corrugated arena.

Related: Dejan Lovren’s header rescues point for Liverpool against Napoli

You can’t kill the spirit and Jürgen Klopp’s team duly rallied. Jordan Henderson – who had another driving game – switched to right-back. The gears began to crunch, the engine to turn. Dejan Lovren’s header from a James Milner corner levelled the score at 1-1, as it would stay. At the end of which Liverpool need a point in Salzburg to progress, no mean feat against a fizzy, peppy, caffeinated young team. Of equal concern for Klopp will be the loss of an opportunity to rest players in a fortnight’s time.

What is it with these blue shirts? When it comes to Liverpool, Napoli just seem to know something other teams don’t. They seem to know they’re playing Joe Gomez and James Milner, not some brain‑mangling red swarm, to know that winning chemistry can be broken down.

The essence of Klopp’s achievement has been to make these components coalesce and work as a single high-functioning unit, driving a disparate set of players on to become the best club side in the world. Alone among their regular opponents, Napoli seem to have the ability to swish back the curtain and expose the parts.

Klopp played a strong team here. Only Georginio Wijnaldum and Trent Alexander-Arnold were rested. At kick-off the Kop end was the usual fond, warm pageantry of flags and scarves and banners, with that strange kind of electricity that seems to thicken the air a little on nights like these.

But there were misfires and missed beats from the start. Napoli left no space, no angles to make those killer diagonal passes. There was no room in that low blue block for the front three to create the usual whirl of movement.

Probably Liverpool were due a game like this. Some of the players had begun to look a little tired. The loss of Fabinho with a foot injury after 20 minutes disrupted the flow. They also missed their playmaker here. Without Alexander‑Arnold the flatness of the midfield is suddenly an issue. There is no comparison with Gomez on the right flank, a converted centre-half who looked like one here, slowing the play on his side of the pitch like the squeaky wheel on a wonky supermarket trolley.

Plus, of course, Napoli are a seriously good team, with a coach in Carlo Ancelotti who knows how to twang away at those tender points in a Klopp team. The opening goal echoed Napoli’s success down the flanks in their 2-0 win in Naples.

As Liverpool pressed high the ball was turned over and Giovanni Di Lorenzo lofted a pass in behind Andy Robertson. Dries Mertens was ready, haring off alone into all that green space. He let the ball bounce, let it bounce again and then smashed a thrilling low shot across Alisson and into the far corner.

Premier League teams really could do a lot worse than study the tapes of these 180 Champions League minutes. It’s a simple plan. Defend deep, break quickly, look for the long pass in behind the full-backs. Above all, don’t see red-shirted furies in front of you. Napoli’s players were calm, stayed compact and saved their adrenaline. It helps, of course, if you can defend like an Italian team. Spurs tried something here and were eaten alive.

When in doubt, send for more Henderson. Just past the hour mark Klopp removed Gomez, put the captain at right-back and almost instantly the game changed. Liverpool began to crank up through the higher registers, to switch the ball from side to side with some of that familiar disorientating vim.

The goal was coming: it duly arrived on 65 minutes. And for a while as Liverpool’s fans absorbed the sense of resale, scarves twirling, this was a beautiful sporting spectacle, the players moving as blocks of blue and red under those brilliant white lights. Liverpool had done it again, wearing their opponents down relentlessly. But Napoli gave them plenty to ponder; not to mention a lesson – who knows – for the rest of the league in how to resist that rising tide.

webTitle: City investors urge UK's top firms to pay workers living wage

fields.headline: City investors urge UK's top firms to pay workers living wage
fields.standfirst: Letter addresses companies including Royal Mail, British Airways and JD Sports
fields.trailText: Letter addresses companies including Royal Mail, British Airways and JD Sports
fields.body:
Influential City investors have written to the chief executives of companies including Royal Mail, British Airways and JD Sports urging them to pay their workers a real living wage.

The letter calls on businesses to seek accreditation from the Living Wage Foundation, which makes sure companies pay employees and contractors an hourly rate higher than the national minimum. Signatories include the UK’s largest asset manager, Legal & General Investment Management, Candriam Investors Group, BMO Global Asset Management and responsible investment group Hermes EOS. The investors together control almost £2tn in assets.

The foundation’s real living wage – calculated as “what employees and their families need to live” – is £9.30 an hour across the UK, or £10.75 in higher-cost London. That contrasts with the £8.21 legal minimum for over-25s – dubbed the “national living wage” by the former chancellor George Osborne – or the £7.70 minimum wage for the under-25s.

Concern over low pay for employees has risen up the political agenda since the financial crisis, with British workers enduring the worst decade for real-terms pay growth since the Napoleonic wars of 1803–1815, according to the Resolution Foundation thinktank. At the same time, executive pay has risen dramatically.

More than 5,500 employers are accredited as living wage employers, but only 38 of the companies listed on the FTSE-100 index have signed up so far.

Pauline Lecoursonnois, who negotiates with companies for Hermes EOS, said: “The case is clear: a workforce that is fairly paid, well valued and respected will perform better than one that isn’t and therefore we are asking UK companies to consider paying the living wage as a key indicator of a responsible and sustainable business.”

Royal Mail, whose workers are appealing in court to try to strike over the Christmas period, was among the recipients of the letter. A spokesman said the “vast majority” of its employees earned more than the living wage.

Hargreaves Lansdown, the FTSE-100 investment platform, said it planned to gain living wage accreditation in response to the letter, which was organised by ShareAction, a campaign group.

The government-appointed Low Pay Commission on Wednesday delayed its publication of its recommendation for the national living wage, citing the purdah period ahead of the general election.

Other companies who received letters were the takeaway app Just Eat, the software company Aveva, the bookmaker Flutter Entertainment, and the manufacturers Halma and Smurfit Kappa.

Four of the companies had still not signed up to the living wage despite having faced investor pressure on the issue over the past year. They were IAG, which owns British Airways, the United Utilities water company, the pest control and cleaning company Rentokil Initial, and the Irish industrial group DCC.

BA said all its workers were paid more than the legal minimums. Rentokil said only a small number of workers were paid below the living wage as a starting salary. United Utilities and Just Eat said all direct employees were paid the living wage.

The property developer British Land said it pays all direct employees the living wage, but could not guarantee the pay rates of outsourced suppliers such as cleaning contractors.

webTitle: William Blake's final work to be projected on St Paul's Cathedral

fields.headline: William Blake's final work to be projected on St Paul's Cathedral
fields.standfirst: Artist of unfulfilled grand ambitions to light up London night with Ancient of Days
fields.trailText: Artist of unfulfilled grand ambitions to light up London night with Ancient of Days
fields.body:
William Blake always dreamed of making vast works for churches and palaces but to his bitter disappointment he never achieved it.

More than two centuries after his death Tate has announced it is going some way to making up for that by projecting his final work on to the giant dome of St Paul’s Cathedral.

Related: William Blake review – blazing heresies from the artist who blows Constable and Turner away

For four evenings from Thursday, his illustration, Ancient of Days, will dramatically light up the skyline of London.

Martin Myrone, the senior curator of pre-1800 art at Tate Britain, said Blake always had grand ambitions as an artist, proposing huge frescoes that were never realised. “Everything that survives of his work is very small. Many of his works are just a few inches high,” he said.

“What he said he wanted to do was produce altarpieces and large-scale pictorial schemes in churches and palaces. This is a moment to realise a version at least of that lifelong dream of Blake’s to be an artist with real public impact who was being seen on a large scale.”

Blake is regarded as a visionary, radical artist who was ahead of his time and unappreciated for most of his life.

“He had a frustrating career and had moments when he was really down and depressed,” said Myrone. “He felt alienated from the art establishment and he never really won the audience that he wished to have.

Related: Heavenly visions of hell: Alan Moore on the sublime art of William Blake

“He did see himself as an artist who should be read and seen by not just a few connoisseurs but by lots and lots of people.”

The project, which marks his birthday, stems from Tate Britain’s current exhibition of Blake, the biggest for a generation, which runs until February and includes digital enlargements of works he imagined as vast frescoes on public buildings.

The St Paul’s dome takes it to another level and is an appropriate venue because it is home to a memorial to Blake. His body was buried in an unmarked grave in Bunhill Fields burial ground near Old Street in London.

Myrone said Blake was a contrary, argumentative person. “I think he would hopefully recognise that we are acknowledging him not as an easy figure but as a major presence in British cultural life.”

webTitle: 'Best time ever': school-leavers have pick of university courses, says Ucas

fields.headline: 'Best time ever': school-leavers have pick of university courses, says Ucas
fields.standfirst: Competition is fierce between institutions recruiting from shrinking pool of 18-year-olds
fields.trailText: Competition is fierce between institutions recruiting from shrinking pool of 18-year-olds
fields.body:
Today’s school-leavers are enjoying “the best time ever” to take their pick of university courses, thanks to fierce competition between institutions recruiting from a shrinking pool of 18-year-olds, according to the UK’s university admissions administrator.

Ucas, which operates the admissions process for undergraduate courses, said nearly 98% of applicants received offers of a place to study for a degree this year, and that could be even higher next year as the demographic dip among British school-leavers reaches its lowest point.

“Considering the likely impact of the further decline in the 18-year-old population, and the expansion of applicant choice in the admissions process, now may be the best time ever for students to realise their higher education ambitions,” Ucas said in its review of 2019 application statistics.

Related: Charity regulator warns Ucas about marketing loans to students

The figures lay bare the intense scramble among universities relying on undergraduate tuition fees. The analysis by Ucas showed that most universities extended offers to more than four out of every five applicants, while even those institutions requiring the highest A-level grades were not far behind in all but the most prestigious courses.

A record rate of 34% of UK 18-year-olds entered higher education in 2019, a total of 241,515. Of the remaining 66%, many are likely to enter higher education before they turn 30, based on current trends.

Clare Marchant, Ucas’s chief executive, said the figures “show the unprecedented opportunity for anyone currently thinking of applying to university to be ambitious with their choices. The trends identified through our analysis are very likely to continue into this year, with universities, colleges, and schools continuing to support students from a variety of backgrounds.”

Many students took advantage of the “buyer’s market” by using Ucas’s post-results clearing service to hunt for improved offers, with 73,000 applicants – more than one in eight – finding places. Thousands took advantage of a new option to “self-release” from previously accepted offers, many in hope of finding a more attractive choice.

Students with predicted A-level grades of AAB or ABB were the most in demand overall, with an 87% likelihood of receiving an offer from each university to which they applied. About 39% of applicants received competing offers from each of their maximum of five choices.

Ucas’s end-of-cycle analysis noted that universities have expanded their use of contextual offers to attract applicants from disadvantaged backgrounds. But it found that only 17% of the most disadvantaged applicants reported receiving one, while others remain unaware of their use.

Geoff Barton, the general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said Ucas was wrong to suggest teachers should do more to “familiarise” themselves with contextual offers.

“This is easier said than done. Ucas itself acknowledges that contextualised admissions practices vary substantially between higher education providers. And schools and colleges have suffered years of real-terms cuts which means they are simply unable to provide the level of student support that they would like to be able to offer,” Barton said.

Related: Record number of disadvantaged pupils get university places

Barton also noted the “worrying decline” in applications to study mathematical sciences, which has been attributed to the tougher maths curriculum in England and fewer students taking the subjects at A-levels.

“It is hard to escape the conclusion that some students have been put off maths by the difficulty of the new so-called ‘big, fat’ maths GCSE,” Barton said.

“We hope the decline in entries turns out to be a blip but it is important the government reviews what has happened and addresses any problems. A decline in maths undergraduates stores up problems for the future.”

Ucas also revealed that demand for places on nursing courses has recovered after the government’s 2017 decision to scrap bursaries. In 2019 a record 30,000 students accepted places on nursing courses across the UK, including 23,000 from England.
